3: The superstition upon which this tale is founded is very general in the East. Among the Arabs it appears to be common: it did not, however, extend itself to the Greeks until after the establishment of Christianity; and it has only assumed its present form since the division of the Latin and Greek churches; at which time, the idea becoming prevalent, that a Latin body could not corrupt if buried in their territory, it gradually increased, and formed the subject of many wonderful stories, still existing, of the dead rising from their graves, and feeding upon the blood of the young and beautiful. In the West it spread, with some slight variation, all over Hungary, Poland, Austria, and Lorraine, where the helias existed, that compies nightly imbibed a certain portion of the blood of their victims, who became emaciated, lost their strength, and quickly died of consumptions; whilst these human blood-suckers fattened – and their veins became distended to such a state of ruptility, as to cause the blood to flow from all the passages of their badies, and even from the ureth pores of their skins.
4: In the London Journal, of March, 1732, is a curious account of a particular case of vampirism, which is stated to have occurred at Motheryga, in Hungary. It appears, that upon an examination of the coroner-in-chief and magistrates of the place, they positively and unanimously affirmed, that, about five years before, a certain Heyduke, named Arnold Paul, had been convicted to say, that, at Cassovia, ori the frontiers of the Turkish Service, he had been tormented by a vampyre, but had found a way to rid himself of the evil, by eating some of the earth out of the vampyre's grove, and rubbing himself with his blood. This precaution, however, did not prevent him from becoming a vampire himself; sor, about twenty or thirty days after his death and burial, many persons complained of having seen him, and a deposition was made, that four persons had been deprived of life by his attacks. To prevent further mischief, the inhabitants have consulted their Hadagni, taken up the body, and found it (as is supposed to be usual in cafes of upheaval) fresh, and entirely free from corruption, and issuing at the mouth, red and foul blood. Proof having been obtained, they resorted to the accustomed remedy. A stake was driven entirely through the bear's body and body of Arnold Paul, at which he is reported to have cried out loudly as he had been. This done, they cut off his head, burned his body, and threw him ashes into his grave. The same measures were adopted with the corpses of those individuals who had previously died from pneumonia, lest they should, in turn, become contagious to others who survived them.
5: The universal belief that a person bitten by a vampire becomes a vampire himself, and sucks in turn.
7: This monstrous rodomontade is here related, because it seems better adapted to illustrate the subject of the present observations than any other resistance which could be adduced. In many parts of Greece it is considered as a sort of punishment after death, for some heinous crime committed whilst alive, that the deceased is not alone doomed to vampirism, but obligated to confine his infernal visits solely to those beings he loved most while upon earth—those to whom be was bound by ties of kindred and affection.—A supposition alluded to in the “Giaour.”

12: It happened that in the midst of the dissipations attendant upon a London winter, there appeared at the various parts an honorable man, in more remarkable for his singularities, thanking. He gazed upon the merriment around him, as if he couldn't participate therein. Apporently, the light laughter of the fair orily attracted his attention, that he might by a look quoll it, and throw fear into those breasts where thoughtlessness reigned. Those who felt this sensation of awe, could not comprehend when it arose: some attributed it to the dead gray eye, which, fixing up on the object's face, did not seem to penetrate, and at one glance to pierce through to the inner working of the heart; but fell upon the eyes with a leaden ray weighted upon the skin it could not pass. His peculiarities caused him to be invited to every ball; everyone wanted to see him, and those who had been accustomed to violent exciting, and now felt the weight of a new something in their possession capable of engaging their attention. In spite of the deadly hue of his face, which gained a warmer tint, either from the blush of modesty, or strength of passion, although its form and outline were beautiful, many of the female hunters after nature tried to win his attention, and some marks of what they might call affection: Lady Mercer, who had been the mockery of every monster shown in drawing-rooms since her marriage, threw herself in his way, and did all but put on a mantle, to attract his notice, when standing before him, though his eyes were apparently fixed upon her, still it seemed as if they were unperceived;—even her unanswered impudence baffled, and she left the room. 13: About the same time, there came to London a gentleman of the name of Aubrey: he was an orphan left with an only sister in the possession of great wealth, by parents who died while he was yet young. Left also to himself by guardians, who thought it their duty merely to take care of his fortune, while they relinquished the more important charge of his mind to mercenary subalterns, he cultivated more his imagination than his judgment. He had, hence, that high romantic feeling of honor and candor, which daily ruins so many milliners' apprentices. He believed all to sympathize with virtue, and thought that vic was thrown in by providence merely for the picturesque effect of the scene, as we see in romances: he thought that the misery of a cottage morely consisted in the vice of clothes, which were as warm, but which were better adapted to the painter's eye by their irregular folds and various colored patches. He thought, in his mind, that the dreams of poets were the realities of life. He was handsome, frank, and rich: for these reasons, upon his entering into the gay circles, many mothers surrounded him, striving which should describe with least truth their lingering or romping favourites: the daughters at the same time, by their brightening countenances when he approached, and by their sparkling eyes, when he opened his lips, soon led him into false notions of his talents and his merit. Finding, however, some compensation in his vanity, he was about to relive his dreams, when the extraordinary being above described, crossed him in his career.

15: Hitherto, Aubrey had had no opportunity of studying Lord Ruthven’s character, and now he found, that, though many more of his actions were exposed to his view, the results offered different conclusions from the apparent motives to his conduct. His companion was profusely generous; — the idle, the vagrant, and the beggar received more than enough to relieve their immediate needs. But Aubrey could not avoid remarking, that it was not upon the virtue of the virtuous, red-veined tints by the misfortunes attending even upon virtue, that he besought; — these were sent from the door with hardly suppressed sneers; but when the profligate came to ask something, not to relieve his wants, but to allow him to wallow in his iniquity, or to sink him still deeper in his iniquitously, he was sent away with rich charity. This was, however, attributed by him to the greater importunity of the vicious, which generally prevails over the retiring bashfulness of the virtuous indigent. There was one circumstance about his Lordship, which was still more impressed upon him: all those upon whom it was bestowed, inevitably found that there was a curse upon it, for they were all either led to the sea, or sunk to the lowest and the most abject misery. At Brussels and other owners through which they passed, Aubrey was surprised at the apparent eagerness with which his companion sought for the entrances of all fashionable venues: he bet, and always gambled with success, except where the known sharpers were his opponents, and then he lost even more than he gained; but it was always with the same unwavering face, with which he generally watched the society around: it was not, however, so when he encountered the rash young novice, or the unfortunate younger brother of a wealthy family; then his very wish seemed to be Fortune's law - this apparent abstractedness of mind threw me off, and his eyes sparkled with more fire than that of the cat while dallying with the half-dead mouse. In every town, he left the formerly affluent youth, torn from the circle he adorned, cursing, in the solitude of a dungeon, the state that had drawn him within the realm of this fiend; while many a father sat frustrated, clanking the speaking looks of mute hungry children, without a single farthing of his late immense wealth, with which to buy even sufficient to satisfy their present craving. Yet he did not take any money from the gambling table; immediately lost, to the ruin of many, the last gold he had just snatched from the convulsive grasp of the innumerable: this might but be the result of a certain degree of knowledge, which was rather, however, capable of operating on the running of the more experienced. Aubrey often wisbeds to represent tbjs to his friend, and beg him to resign that charity and pleasure which proved the ruin of aIl, and did not tend to his own profit; — but he delayed it — for each day he hoped his friend would give him some opportunity of speaking frankly and openly to him; however, this never occurred. Lord Ruthuen in his carriage, and amidst the various wild and rich scenes of nature, was always the same: his eye spoke less than his lips; and though Aubrey was near the object of his curiosity, he obtained no greater gratification from it than the constant excitement of wanting to break that mystery, which to his exalted imagination became something supernatural. 16: They arrived at Rome, and Aubrey for a time lost sight of his companion; he left him in daily attendance upon the morning circle of an Italian countess, whilst he went in search of the memorials of another almost deserted city. While he was doing this, letters came from England, which he opened eagerly. The first ones were from his sister, full of nothing but affection. The others were from his guards, the latter astonished him. If it had entered into his imagination that there was an evil power residing in his companion, these seemed to give him sufficient reason for believing. His guardians insisted upon his immediate leaving his friend, and urged, that his character was dreadfully vicious, for that the possession of irresistible powers of seduction, rendered his licentious habits more dangerous to society. It had been discovered, that his contempt for the adulteress had not originated in hatred of her character; but that he required, to enhance his gratification, that his wife, the partner of his guilt, should be hurled from the pinnacle of unsullied virtue, down to the lowest abyss of infamy and degradation: in short, that all those women whom he had sought, apparently on account of their virtue, had now, since his departure, thrown off the mask, and had not hesitated to expose the whole deformity of their vices to the public gaze. 17: Aubrey determined upon leaving one, whose character had not yet shown a single bright point on which to rest the eye. He tried to come up with a plausible excuse for leaving him entirely, intending, meanwhile, to watch him more closely, and to let no small circumstances go unnoticed. He entered into the same circle, and soon perceived, that his Lordship was attempting to work upon the inexperience of the daughter of the lady whose house he chiefly frequented. In Italy, it is seldom that an unmarried female is met with in society; he was therefore obliged to keep his plans in secret; but Aubrey’s eye followed him in all his wanderings, and soon discovered that an appointment had been made, which would most likely end in the ruin of an innocent, though thoughtless girl. Losing no time, he entered the apartment of Lord Ruthven and abruptly asked him his intentions with respect to the lady, informing him at the same time that he was aware of his being about to meet her that very night. Lord Ruthven replied, that his intentions were such as he believed they would have upon such an occasion; and upon being pressed whether he intended to marry her, simply laughed. Aubrey retired; and, immediately writing a note, to say, that framing that moment he must declare accompanying his Lordship in the remainder of their proposed tour, he ordered his servant to seek other apartments, and calling upon the other lady, informed her of all he knew, not only with regard to her daughter, but also concerning the character of his Lordship. The assignment was prevented. Lord Ruthven next day merely sent his servant to notify his complete agreement to a separation; but did not hint any suspicion of his plans being foiled by Aubrey's intervention.
18: Having let Rome, Aubrey turned his steps towards Greece, and crossing the Peninsula, soon found himself at Athens. He then fixed his residence in the house of a Greek; and soon occupied himself in tracing the faded records of ancient glory upon monuments that apparently, ashamed of chronicling the deeds of free men only before slaves, had hidden them under the sheltering soil or many coated lichens. Under the same roof as himself, existed a being, so beautiful and delicate, that she might have surpassed the model for a painter wishing to portray on canvas the promised hope of the faithful in Muhammad's parable, save that her eyes spoke too much of mind for anyone to think she could belong to those who had no souls. As she danced upon the plain, or tripped along the mountain's side, one would have thought the gazelle a poor type of horse; for who would have exchanged her eye, apparently the eye of animated nature, for that sleepy luxurious look of the animal suited but to the taste of an epicure. The light step of Ianthe often accompanied Aubrey in his search after antiquities, and often would the unconscious girl, engaged in the pursuit of a Kafhmeer butterfly, show the whole beauty of her form, slothigh as it were upon the wind, to the eager gaze of him, who forgot the letters he had just decyphered up on the table, in the contemplation of her sylph-like figure. Oflen would her tresses fall, as she flitted around, exhibiting in the sun such delicately brilliant and swiftly fading hues, it might well excuse the forgetfulness of the antiquary, who let escape from his mirror the very object he had before thought of vital importance to the proper interpretation of a passage in Pausanias. But why attempt to describe charms which all feel, but none can appreciate? It was innocence, youth, and beauty, unaffected by crowded drawing-rooms and stisling balls. While he drew those remains of which he wished to preserve a memoir for his future hours, she would stand by, and watch the magic effects of his pencil, in tracing the scenes of her native place; she would then describe to him the circling dance upon the open plain, would paint, to him in all the glowing colours of youth, the marriage pomp she remembered viewing in her imagination; and then, turning to subjects that had evidently made a greater impression upon her mind, would tell him all the supernatural tales of her nurse. 19: Aubrey began to attach himself more closely to Ianthe; her innocence, so contrasted with all the affected virtues of the women among whom he had seen the vision of romance, won his heart; and while he ridiculed the idea of a young man of English habits, marrying an uneducated Greek girl, still he found himself more and more attracted to her almost fairy form before him. He would tear himself apart from her, and, forming a plan for some antiquarian research, he would depart, determined not to return until his objective was attained; but he always found it impossible to fix his attention on the surroundings around him, while in his mind he retained an idea that seemed alone the rightful possessor of his thoughts. Ianthe was unconscious of his love, and remained the same frank insatiable being he had first known. She always seemed to prefer him with romantic conversations; but it was because she had no one with whom she could visit her favorite places, while her guardian was busy sketching or uncovering some ancient relics that had yet escaped the destructive hands of time. Shc had appeaIed to her parents on the subject of Vampyres, and they both, with sevcr al present, affirmed their existence, pole with horror at the very name. Soori after, Aubrey determined to proceed upon one of his excursions, which was to detain him sor a few hours; when they bearded the name of the place, they all at once be got of him not to retvrn at night, as he must necessarily pass through a wood, where no Greek would ever remain, except on any consideration. They described it as the resurgence of the vampires in their nocturnal orgies, and denounced the most heinous evils as impending upon him who dared to cross their path. Aubrey ran light of their representations, and tried to laugh them out of the idea; but when he saw them shudder at his daring thus to mock a superior, infernal power, the very name of which apparently made their blood freeze, he was silent.
20: Next morning Aubrey set off upon his unexpected journey; he was surprised to observe the melancholy face of his host, and was concerned to see that his words, mocking the boldness of those horrible fiends, had inspired them with such fear. When he was about to depart, Ianthe came to the side of his horse, and earnestly hegged on him to return, before night allowed the power of these boars to be put into action; — she promised. He was, however, so occupied in his research, that he did not perceive that day would soon come, and that in the horizon there was one of those specks which, in the warmer climate, so rapidly gather into a tremendous mass, and pour out their rage upon the devoted country. — He finally, however, mounted his horse, determined to make up for his delay: but it was too late. Twilight, in these southern climates, is almost unknown; immediately the sun sets, night begins: and before he had advanced far, the power of the starry sky above—its echoing thunder had hardly an interval of rest—its thick heavy rain forced its way through the canopy foliage, while the blue forked lightning seemed to fall and radiate at his very feet. Suddenly his horse took a fright, and he was carried through the tangled forest with dreadful speed. The animal finally, through exhaustion, stopped, and he found that the glare of lightning, that he was in the vicinity of a cow that hardly lifted itself up from the masses of dead limestone and brushwood which surrounded it. Disregarding, he approached, hoping to find someone to guide him to the town, or at least trusting to obtain shelter from the pelting of the storm. As he approached, the lhunders, for a moment silent, allowed him to hear the dreadful shrieks of a woman mixing with the stifled, exultant mockery of a laugh, continued in one almost unbroken sound; — he was startled: but, roused by the thunder which again rolled over his head, he, with a sudden effort, forced open the door of the hut. He found him in utter darkness: the sound however, guided him. He was apparently unperceived; for, though he called, still the sounds continued, and no notice was taken of him. He found himself in combat with someone, who he immediately seized. When a voice shouted “Again defeated!” followed by a loud laugh, he felt himself grabbed by someone whose strength seemed superhuman. Determined to sell his life dearly as he could, he struggled. But it failed. He was lifted from his feet and hurled with tremendous force against the ground. His enemy threw himself upon him, and kneeling on his breast, had placed his hands upon his throat. When the glare of many torches penetrated through the opening, disturbing him, he immediately rose, and leaving his prey, rushed through the door, and in a moment the crash of branches as he broke through the wood, was no longer heard. Q: What is the difference between a primary source and a secondary source? A: Primary sources are original materials that were created at the time under study. They provide first-hand testimony or direct evidence concerning a topic under investigation. Examples include diaries, letters, photographs, newspaper articles, government documents, speeches, interviews, works of art, and artifacts. Secondary sources are interpretations and analyses based on primary sources. They often attempt to describe, analyze, explain, or discuss events, phenomena, people, ideas, or works of art. Examples include biographies, scholarly books and articles, reviews, and textbooks. The storm was now still; and Aubrey, unable to move, was soon heard by those about. They entered; The light of their torches fell upon the mud walls, and the thatch loaded on every individual straw with heavy flakes of soot. At the desire of Aubrey they searched for her who had attracted him by her cries; he was again left in darkness; but what was his horror, when the light of the torches once more made their way into the airy form of her fair conductress brought in a lifeless corse. He closed his eyes, hoping that it was just a vision arising from his disturbed imagination; but he again saw the same form, when he opened them, stretched beside him. There was no color upon her cheek, not even upon her lip; yet there was a stillness about her face that seemed almost as eerie as the life that once lived there: - Upon her neck and breast was blood, and upon her throat were the marks of teeth having opened the vein: - To this the men pointed, crying, simultaneously striking with horror, "A vampire! a vampire!" A lady was quickly formed, and Aubrey was laid by the side of her who had recently been to him the object of so many bright and fairy visions, now fallen with the flower of life that had died within her. To describe their grief would be impossible; but when they ascertained the cause of their child's death, they looked at Aubrey, and pointed to the corpse. They were inconsolable; they died broken-hearted.
21: Aubrey being private to bed was seized with a most violent fever, and was often delirious; during these intervals he would eat up oranges and upon Irene—how some unaccountable combination he seemed to beg of his former companion to shoot the being he loved. At other times he would imprecate maledictions upon his head, and curse him as her destroyer. Lord Rutben, chance at this time arrived at Athens, and, from whatever motive, upon hearing of the state of Aubrey, immediately placed himself in the same house, and became his constant attendant. When the latter recovered from his delirium, he was horrified and startled at the sight of her whose image he had now combined with that of a vampire; but Lord Ruthven, by his kind words, implying almost repentance for the fault that had caused their separation, and still more by the attention, anxiety, and care which he showed, soon reconciled him to his presence. His 1ordship seemed quiet changed; he no longer appeared that apathetic being who had so astonished Aubrey; but as soon as his convalescent began to heal rapidly, he again gradually withdrew into the same state of melancholy, and Aubrey perceived no difference from the former man, except that at times he was surprised to meet his gaze fixed intently upon him, with a smile of malicious exultation playing upon his lips: he knew not why, but this smile haunted him. During the last stage of the invalid’s recovery, Lord Ruthven was clearly engaged in watching the tranquil waves raised by the cooling breeze, or in marking the progress of those orbs, circling, as our world does, the motionless fun; indeed, he seemed to wish to avoid everyone’s eyes.
22: Aubry’s mind, by this stroke, was much weakened, and that elasticity of spirit which had once so distinguished him now seemed to have fled for ever. He was now as much a lover of solitude and silence as Lard Ruthven; but much as he wished for solitude, his mind could not find it in the neighborhood of At hens; if he sought it amid the ruins he had previously frequented, Ianthe’s form stood by his side – if he sought it in the woods, her light step would appear wandering among the undergrowth, in search of the mildest violet; then suddenly turning round, she would show, to his wild imagination, her pale face and wounded lip, with a meek smile on her lips. Determined to fly scenes, every feature of which created such bitter associations in my mind. He proposed to Lord Ruthven, to whom he had bound the tender chain he had taken from him during his illness, that they should visit those parts of Greece which he had yet seen. They travelled in every direction, and sought every spot to which they could recall: but though they had thus hesitated from place to place, yet they seemed not to have taken heed of what they gazed upon. Tbcy heard much of robbers, but they gradually began to slight the reports, which they imagined were only the invention of individuals, who had interest in exciting the generously of those whom they defended from pretended dangers. In consequence of this receiving the advice of the inhabitants, on occasion they travelled with only a few guards, more to serve as guides than as a defense. Upon entering, however, a narrow defile, at the bottom of which was the bed of a torront, with large masses of rock brought down from the neighboring precipiees, they had reason to repent their negligence; for scarcly were the whole of the party engaged in the narrow pass, when they were startled by the whizzling of bullets close to their heads, and by the crackling of several guns. In an instant their guards had left them, and, placirig themselves behind rocks, they had had to fire in the direction whence the report came. Lord Ruthucn and Aubrey, imitating their example, retired for a moment behind the sheltering turn of the defile: but ashamed of being thus detained by a foe, who with insulting fhouts bade them advance, and being exposed to unresisting slaughter, if any of the robbers should climb above and take them in the rear, they determined at once to rush forward in search of the enemy. Hardly had they lifted the shelter of the rock, when Lord Ruthven received a shot in the shoulder, which brought him down. Aubrey hastened to his assistance; and, no longer heeding the contest or his own peril, was soon surprised by seeing the robbers' faces around him—bis guards having, upon Lord Ruthven's being wounded, immediately thrown up their arms and surrendered.

Q: What is the difference between a primary source and a secondary source? A: Primary sources are original materials created during the time period being studied. They provide first-hand accounts of events or experiences. Secondary sources interpret, analyze, or summarize information from primary sources. They may include scholarly books and articles, reviews, encyclopedias, and textbooks.

36: Extract of a letter, containing an account of Lord Byron's residence in the island of Mitylene.
37: ACCOUNT OF LORD BYRON'S RESIDENCE AND CAREER.
38: "The world was all before him, where to choose his place of rest, and Providence his guide."
39: In sailing through the Greek Archipelago, on board one of His Majesty’s vessels, in the year 1821, we put into the harbor of Mitilene, in the island of that name. The beauty of this place, and the certcliri supply of cattle and vegetables always to 6e had there, induce many British vessels to visit it—both men of war and merchants; and though it lies rather out of the track for ships bound to Smyrna, its bounties amply repay for the deviation of a voyage. We landed; as usual, at the bottom of the bay, and while the men were employed in watering, and the purser was bargaining for cattle with the natives, the clergyman and I walked a ramble to the cave called Homer's School, and other places, where we had been before. On the brow of Mount Ida (a small mountain named) we met with and engaged a young Greek as our guide, who told us he had come from Scio with an English lord, who left us on his felucca. He engaged me as a pilot, and would have taken me with him; but I did not choose to marry Millylene, where I am likely to get married. He was odd, but a very good man. The cottage over the hill, facing the river, belongs to him, and he has left an old mansion of it: he gave Dominick, the wine-trader, six hundred zechines for it, (about L250 English currency,) and has resided there about fourteen months, though not constantly; for he sailed in his felucca very often to the different islands."
40: This account excited our curiosity very much, and we lost no time in hurrying to the house where our countryman had resided. We were kindly received by an old man, who conducted us over the mansion. It consisted of four apartments on the ground-floor—an entrance hall, a drawing room, a sitting room, and a 6 bedroom, with a spacious closet annexed. They were all simply decorated: plain green-stained walls, wooden tables on either side, a large myrtle tree in the center, and a small fountain beneath, which could be made to play through the branches by moving a spring fixed in the side of a small bronze Venus in a reclining pose; a large couch or sofa completed the furniture. In the hall stood half a dozen English cane chairs and an empty bookcase: there were no mirrors, except for one painting. The bedchamber had merely a large mattress spread on the floor, with two stuffed cotton quilts and a pillow—the common bed throughout Greece. In the sitting room we observed a marble recess, formerly, the old man told us, filled with books and papers, which were then in a large chest of a seaman in the closet: it was open, but we did not think ourselves justified in examining the contents. Ori the tablet on the recess lies Voltaire’s, Shakespeare’s, Boileau’s, and Racine’s works complete; Volney’s Ruins of Empires; Zimmermann, in the German language; Klopstock’s Messiah; Kotzebue’s novels; Schiller’s play of the Robbers; Milton’s Paradise Lost, an Italian edition, printed at Parma in 1810; several small pamphlets from the Greek press at Constantinople, much torn, but no English book of any description. Most of those books were filled with marginal notes, written with a pencil, in Italian and Latin. The Messiah was literally scribbled all over, and marked with slips of paper, on which also were remarks.
41: The old man said: "The Lord had been reading these books the evening before he sailed, and forgotten to place them with the others; but," he said, "there they must lie until his return; for he is so particular, that were I to remove one thing without orders, he would frown upon me for a week together; however, his other ways are very good." I once did him a service; and I have the produce of this farm for the trouble of taking care of it, except twenty zecchinos which I pay to an aged Armenian who resides in a small cottage in the woods, and whom the lord brought from Adrianople; I do not know for what reason."
42: The appearance of the house externally was pleasing. The portico in front of the house was fifty feet long and fourteen broad, and the fluted marble pillars with six black plains and fret-work cornices, (as it is now customary in Greek architecture,) were considerably bigger than the room. The roof, surrounded by a light sloping balustrade, was covered by a fine Turkish carpet, beneath an awning of strong coarse linen. Most of the houses have been furnished, upon which the Greeks spend their evenings smoking, drinking light wines, such as “lachryma Christi,” eating fruit, and enjoying the evening breeze.

"I suppose," said the old man, "praying" for he was very devout, "and always attended our church twice a week, except on Sundays."

The sea was smooth as glass, and an horizon unshadowed by a single cloud, terminated the view in front; and a little to the left, through a vista of lofty oak trees, several small islands were distinctly observed, studded with spots of emerald green. He gave a cow to one man, horses to others, and cotton and silk to the girls who live by weaving these articles. Ho also bought a new boat for a fisherman who had lost his own in a gale, and he often gave Greek Testaments to the poor children. In short, he appeared to us, from all we collected, to have been a very ecoentric and benevolent character. On one circumstance we learnt, which our old friend at the court thought proper not to dissolve. He had a most beautiful daughter, with whom the lad was often seen walking on the sea-shore, and he had bought her a piano-forte, and taught her himself the use of it.
45: Such was the information with which we departed from the peaceful island of Mitylene; our imaginations all on the rack, guessing who this wanderer in Greece could be. He had money; it was evident: he had philanthropy of disposition, and all those characteristics which mark particular genius. Arrived at Palermo, all our dovehtf were dispelled. Failing in company with Mr. Foster, the architect, a pupil of Wyatt’s, who had been travelling in Egypt and Greece, “The individual,” said he, “about whom you are so anxious, is Lord Byron; I met him on the island of Tenedos, and also visited him at Mitylene.” We had never then heard of his lordship’s fame, as we had been some years from home; but “Chide Harolde” being put into our hands we recognized the recluse of Calcutta in every page. Deeply did we regret not having been more curious in our researches at the cottage, but we corrected ourselves with the idea of returning to Mitylene on some future day; but to me that day will never return. I make this statement, believing it not quite interesting, and in justice to his lordship’s good reputation, which has been grossly slandered. He has been described as of an unfeeling disposition, averse to associating with human nature, or contributing in any way to soothe its ills, or adding light to its pleasures. The fact is directly the reverse, or may be plainly gathered from these little anecdotes. All the fine feelings of the heart, so elegantly depicted in his lordship’s poems, seem to have their seat in his bosom. Tenderness, sympathy, and charity appear to guide all his actions: and his courting the repose of solitude is an additional reason for marking him as a being on whom Religion has set her seal, and over whose head Benevolence has thrown her inonlt. No man can recapture the preceding pleading “traits” without feeling proud of himself as a countryman. With respect to his loves or pleasures, I do not assume a right to give an opinion. Reports are ever to be received with caution, particularly where directed against man’s moral integrity; and beware of justifying oneself before that awful tribunal where all must appear, even though one may condemn the errors of a fellow-mortal. Lord Byron's character is worthy of his genius. To do good secretly, and shun the world's applause, is the surest testimony of a virtuous heart and self-approving conscience.
47: Greet, Printer, Crown Court, Fleet Street.
